etymologies: Old English gif, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch of and German ob

notes.text: If and whether are more or less interchangeable in sentences like I'll see if he left an address and I'll see whether he left an address, although whether is generally regarded as more formal and suitable for written use. But, although if and whether are often interchangeable, a distinction worth noting is that if is also used in conditional constructions and whether in expressing an alternative or possibility. Thus, tell me if you're going to be in town next week could be strictly interpreted as ‘you need not reply if you are not going to be in town,’ whereas tell me whether you're going to be in town next week clearly means ‘a reply is desired one way or the other.’

definitions: (introducing a conditional clause) on the condition or supposition that; in the event that

examples.text: if you have a complaint, write to the director
if you like I'll put in a word for you

definitions: (with past tense) introducing a hypothetical situation

examples.text: if you had stayed, this would never have happened
if I go out she gets nasty

definitions: despite the possibility that; no matter whether

examples.text: if it takes me seven years, I shall do it
he asked if we would like some coffee
see if you can track it down
if you wouldn't mind giving him a message?
if I could trouble you for your names?
that's an awfully long walk, if you don't mind my saying so
if you ask me, he's in love
if I could just be left alone
the new leaders have little if any control

definitions: used to admit something as being possible but regarded as relatively insignificant

examples.text: if there was any weakness, it was naiveté

shortDefinitions: admitting something as possible but insignificant

definitions: despite being (used before an adjective or adverb to introduce a contrast)

examples.text: she was honest, if a little brutal
